description: From Middle French prosaïque, from Medieval Latin prosaicus (“in prose”), from Latin prosa (“prose”), from prorsus (“straightforward, in prose”), from Old Latin provorsus (“straight ahead”), from pro- (“forward”) + vorsus (“turned”), from vertō (“to turn”), from Proto-Indo-European *wer- (“to turn, to bend”).

adjectives.description: prosaic (comparative more prosaic, superlative most prosaic)

entries.meaning: Pertaining to or having the characteristics of prose.
examples: The tenor of Eliot's prosaic work differs greatly from that of his poetry.

entries.meaning: (of writing or speaking) Straightforward; matter-of-fact; lacking the feeling or elegance of poetry.
examples: I was simply making the prosaic point that we are running late.

entries.meaning: (main usage, usually of writing or speaking but also figurative) Overly plain, simple or commonplace, to the point of being boring.
examples: Synonyms: humdrum, dull, unimaginative; see also Thesaurus:boring
His account of the incident was so prosaic that I nodded off while reading it.
